description.narrative: The proposed transaction is expected to have a high impact as it will (i) recapitalize one of Guatemala's leading banks and improve the banking systems' solvency; (ii) enable south-to-south investments as part of GyT Continental's strategic plan to expand in the region; (iii) help overcome the low banking penetration still prevalent in Guatemala; and (iv) potentially reduce fragmentation as weaker players may become targets for stronger market participants.

The proposed transaction would qualify as an investment for the IFC Capitalization Fund (the CapFund) as GyT Continental is one of five systemic banks in Guatemala and has a 20.55% and 19.31% market share in terms of total assets and total deposits, respectively as of July 2010. This second investment in GyT Continental would consist of (i) common or preferred shares for up to $32.1 million (Tier I capital), and (ii) subordinated debt for up to $42.9 million (Tier II capital) and would be sourced from the CapFund.
IFC committed its first transaction with GyT Continental in a 9.722% equity stake through a $70 million investment in preferred convertible shares in July 2008, which buttressed GyT Continentals capital at a crucial time and allowed the Bank to weather the economic slowdown in Guatemala.
